text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single-column page with a horizontal miniature inserted between the rubric and the main text. The image occupies full text width, separated by framing lines; text blocks above and below are aligned uniformly. Wide margins are left blank except for floriated penwork initial extending into lower margin.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata for main black text with red Gothic textura cursiva rubrics; executed in a professional book hand with clear vertical strokes, consistent letterforms, extensive use of ligatures and abbreviations.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf used for architectural highlights and diapered backgrounds, signaling sacred space. Ultramarine blue grounds the central scene, contrasting with vermilion red garments to draw attention to key figures. Verdigris green accents at the base support naturalism. Lead white applied for facial highlights and drapery folds. Colors remain vibrant, suggesting minimal pigment degradation.

features: Centralized anointing scene with flanking attendants
Horizontal arrangement guiding eye from left clerics to right nobles

decorative_elements: Gothic micro-architecture with trefoil arches and pinnacles
Diapered red and blue background patterns
Floriated initial 'U' in blue and red with penwork flourishes

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen outlines with varying line weight; bold contours around figures and fine internal details in drapery and faces.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with minimal hatching; white highlights on robes and faces to suggest volume.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping figures indicate depth; no true vanishing-point perspective.

content_theme.scene_description: A single coronation scene occupies the miniature: on the left, three mitred clerics in red and white vestments stand in adoration, one holding a crozier; center shows a kneeling figure clad in a red tunic and mantle, hands raised in prayer; to the right of center, a bishop in a white mitre and red chasuble stands behind a small altar holding a chalice of oil in his left hand and blessing the kneeling figure with his right. On the far right, four nobles in alternating red and blue robes stand with hands raised; one holds a sheathed sword vertically, symbolizing royal authority. All figures are similar in scale; the kneeling figure is slightly lower, emphasizing humility. The architectural frame of three pointed arches with gold spandrels and patterned backgrounds organizes the composition. Costumes include embroidered hems on chasubles, visible fur linings on mantles, and jeweled mitres. The bishop’s altar table bears a white cloth and a small open vessel. Spatially, the grouping creates a clear foreground; overlapping feet and robes suggest depth. Gesture and eye‐line direct focus to the anointing act at center.

religious: Bishop in mitre and chasuble performing blessing
secular: Kneeling king in red tunic and mantle

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform cream color and fine grain; flesh side used for this folio; ruled with plummet underdrawings visible around text and image margins.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments remain vivid with minimal flaking; slight cockling at margins; gold leaf intact and well-adhered; evidence of modern conservation consolidating edges.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf in arches
Confident underdrawing visible under UV light
Regular plummet ruling for text and image borders

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Royal chapel clergy and the monarch

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature likely originates from a mid-13th-century pontifical produced in a northern French workshop for use in royal coronation ceremonies. The sumptuous application of gold and ultramarine, together with the crisp Gothic textura script and precise penwork flourishes, reflects the high-status patronage of the French crown. The three-arched micro-architectural frame situates the sacral act within a symbolic ecclesiastical space, underscoring the theological foundation of kingship as divinely sanctioned. The combination of red and blue garments conforms to northern French color conventions of the period, while the slight overlapping and hierarchical scaling demonstrate advances in spatial representation characteristic of the Île-de-France illumination style. Iconographically, the bishop’s mitre and crozier align the ceremony with episcopal authority, conflating royal and ecclesiastical power, while the attendant bearing the sword evokes medieval theories of sacral monarchy. Comparisons with the Coronation Pontifical of Sens reveal shared compositional patterns and pigment recipes, suggesting a network of collaborative ateliers. This scene underscores the intertwined political and religious dynamics of capetian rule, offering a visual assertion of legitimacy that resonated in both liturgical performance and manuscript culture.
